title: --timeout option causing idle "i/o timeout"
body:
Great work on rclone, I'm a big fan.  Here is my environment...

> Version = rclone v1.33-DEV
> OS = OSX 10.11.6 (El Capitan)
> Storage = Amazon Cloud Drive
> Command =
> 
>  rclone --verbose --retries 3 --max-size 50G --checkers 4 --transfers 1 --stats 10s copy /Volumes/PhotoArchive/Lightroom/2016 remote:Lightroom/2016

When copying with the above command, I noticed that "i/o errors" were occurring for large files whenever the file upload time crossed 5 minutes.  But the "--stats" option shows that data is being continuously uploaded (I/O is not idle).  Here is an example where data is uploading fine, but the upload is interrupted after 5 minutes and restarted again...

> 2016/10/04 13:27:26
> Transferred:   376.469 MBytes (1.315 MBytes/s)
> Errors:                 0
> Checks:              9736
> Transferred:            0
> Elapsed time:     4m46.2s
> Transferring:
> -                2016-04-17/MontereyMinnows.mp4: 78% done. avg: 1420.9, cur: 1412.1 kByte/s. ETA: 1m13s
> 
> 2016/10/04 13:27:41
> Transferred:   394.625 MBytes (1.310 MBytes/s)
> Errors:                 0
> Checks:              9736
> Transferred:            0
> Elapsed time:      5m1.2s
> Transferring:
> -                2016-04-17/MontereyMinnows.mp4: 82% done. avg: 1411.4, cur: 1283.5 kByte/s. ETA: 1m6s
> 
> 2016/10/04 13:27:55 pacer: Rate limited, sleeping for 947.77941ms (1 consecutive low level retries)
> 2016/10/04 13:27:55 pacer: low level retry 1/1 (error Post https://content-na.drive.amazonaws.com/cdproxy/nodes?suppress=deduplication: read tcp 192.168.0.11:56395->52.87.95.4:443: i/o timeout)
> 2016/10/04 13:27:55 2016-04-17/MontereyMinnows.mp4: Received error: Post https://content-na.drive.amazonaws.com/cdproxy/nodes?suppress=deduplication: read tcp 192.168.0.11:56395->52.87.95.4:443: i/o timeout - low level retry 1/10
> 2016/10/04 13:27:55 pacer: Resetting sleep to minimum 20ms on success
> # !/bin/sh
> 
> 2016/10/04 13:27:56
> Transferred:   413.250 MBytes (1.307 MBytes/s)
> Errors:                 0
> Checks:              9736
> Transferred:            0
> Elapsed time:     5m16.2s
> Transferring:
> -                2016-04-17/MontereyMinnows.mp4:  0% done. avg: 1842.7, cur:    0.0 kByte/s. ETA: -

I suspected the "--timeout" option which is "5m" by default.  When I change "--timeout" to 0 (zero), the "i/o timeout" error occurs immediately (endless loop, but should disable timeouts).  When I change "--timeout" to a long time (ie: "8h"), the large files upload successfully without being interrupted.

It appears that the "--timeout" option is falsely interrupting the transfer even though data is being continuously uploaded.  Any insight appreciated.  Thanks!
